revision.text:
{{20th century in Angola}} In the '''1920s in Angola''' mining became the primary source of revenue for the colonial government.<ref name=a>{{cite book|last=Boahen|first=A. Adu|year=1990|title=Africa Under Colonial Domination, 1880-1935|page=171}}</ref>
==Economy== Comphania de Diamantes de Angola, the [[Diamang]] diamond company of Angola, was established in 1920. The government maintained a 5% stake in the company, gave it a thirty-year lease to mine diamonds, and allowed it to operate without paying taxes or import tariffs. The company employed 10,000 workers and attracted investment from [[South Africa]]. In 1922, the Anglo American diamond company purchased a 16% stake in [[Diamang]]. The [[London Diamond Syndicate]] agreed to buy {{convert|125000|carat|kg}} from [[Angola]] annually. Under the rule of Governor General Norton de Matos, the colonial government spent 13 million pounds to bring 9,000 immigrants from [[Portugal]], expanding construction of [[Benguela railway]] and roads. The settler population reached 36,000 by 1924.<ref name=b>{{cite book|last=Fage|first=John Donnelly|year=1986|title=The Cambridge History of Africa|pages=526–527}}</ref> By 1929, mined resources made up 25% of Angola's exports, 600,000 pound sterling.<ref name=a/>
==Colonial governors== {{Main|List of colonial governors in 1920|List of colonial governors in 1921|List of colonial governors in 1924|List of colonial governors in 1925|List of colonial governors in 1926|List of colonial governors in 1928|List of colonial governors in 1929}} #Mimoso Guera, Governor-General of Angola (1919-1920) #Visconde de Pedralva, Governor-General of Angola (1920-1921) #João Mendes Ribeiro Norton de Matos, High Commissioner of Angola (1921-1924) #João Augusto Crispiniano Soares, High Commissioner of Angola (1924) #Antero Tavares de Carvalho, High Commissioner of Angola (1924-1925) #Francisco Cunha Rêgo Cháves, High Commissioner of Angola (1925-1926) #António Vicente Ferreira, High Commissioner of Angola (1926-1928) #António Damas Mora, High Commissioner of Angola (1928-1929) #Filomeno da Câmara Melo Cabral, High Commissioner of Angola (1929-1930)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==See also== *[[Portuguese West Africa]]

France | language = French | budget = }} '''''A Few Days of Respite''''' ({{lang-fr|Quelques jours de répit}}) is a 2011 French-Algerian [[drama film]] written and directed by [[Amor Hakkar]].{{cite book |title=International Film Guide 2012 |first=Ian Hayden |last=Smith |year= 2012 |isbn= 978-1908215017 |page= 55}} It competed in the World Cinema section at the [[2011 Sundance Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117944453?refcatid=31 |title=A Few Days of Respite |accessdate=2012-04-06 |work=Variety}} ==Cast== * [[Marina Vlady]] as Yolande * [[Amor Hakkar]] as Moshen * [[Samir Guesmi]] as Hassan * [[Shimon Ben Lulu]] as Le passeur * [[Yves Grenard]] as Le vieil homme sur les voies * [[Stéphanie Saliège]] as La pianiste * [[Sarah Hakkar]] as La fillette à la gare * [[Kim-Kim Nezzar]] as Le père de la fillette (as Kim Nezzar) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|1787787|A Few Days of Respite}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Few Days Of Respite}} [[Category:2011 films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:2010s LGBT-related films]] [[Category:Algerian films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:French drama films]] [[Category:French LGBT-related films]] [[Category:LGBT-related drama films]] {{Algeria-film-stub}} {{2010s-France-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Airline| airline = Air Dream| logo_size = | fleet_size = 1| destinations = 2| IATA = AD| ICAO = ADA| callsign = -| parent = | company_slogan = | founded = 2007[http://www.airlineupdate.com/content_public/airlines/se_asia/cambodia.htm World Airline Directory] {{dead link|date=November 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}| ceased = 2007| headquarters = [[Cambodia]]| key_people = | hubs = | frequent_flyer = | lounge = | alliance = | website = | }} [[File:Air Dream Boeing 727-200 MRD-1.jpg|thumb|Air Dream Boeing 727-200]] '''Air Dream''' was a short-lived [[charter airline]] based in [[Cambodia]]. During 2007, it operated flights between [[Siem Reap]], Cambodia, and Hanoi, [[Vietnam]].[http://english.vietnamnet.vn/social/2008/06/787746/ Vietnam Net News: Foreign aircraft abandoned at Noi Bai Airport] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612222339/http://english.vietnamnet.vn/social/2008/06/787746/ |date=2008-06-12 }}, 10 June 2008. Its single aircraft, chartered from financially troubled [[Royal Khmer Airlines]], was flown to [[Noi Bai International Airport]], [[Hanoi]], in late 2007 for maintenance reasons and abandoned there subsequently, as the airline was shut down.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7446469.stm Plane abandoned at Hanoi airport], BBC, 10 June 2008. Link to photos of aircraft when previously operated by [[Jatayu Airlines]], [[Malaysia]], c. 2005. == Fleet == Air Dream operated one ageing [[Boeing 727-200]] jet airliner, which was originally delivered to [[American Airlines]] in 1988.[http://www.airliners.net/search/photo.search?airlinesearch=Air%20Dream&distinct_entry=true Airliners Net]: photos and data on aircraft from February and May 2008.
[http://www.airliners.net/search/photo.search?regsearch=N848AA&distinct_entry=true These photos from airliners.net] suggest that the aircraft, built in 1975, was operated by [[American Airlines]] until sold to a [[Chicago]] area aircraft maintenance school between 2000 and 2002. It was damaged in high winds, [http://www.airliners.net/photo/Untitled/Boeing-727-223-Adv/0374478&tbl=photo_info&photo_nr=4&prev_id=0386774&next_id=0352366 according to this report], in 2003.[http://www.planespotters.net/search.php?q=n484aa Aircraft fleet register entry on N484AA] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.ch-aviation.ch/aircraft.php?search=set&airline=DRA&al_op=1 Air Dream Fleet] {{commonscat-inline|Air Dream}} {{Airlines of Cambodia}} [[Category:Defunct airlines of Cambodia]] [[Category:Airlines established in 2007]] [[Category:Airlines disestablished in 2007]] [[Category:Cambodian companies established in 2007]] [[Category:Cambodian companies disestablished in 2007]] {{asia-airline-stub}} {{Cambodia-transport-stub}}

revision.text:
{{About||the record producer|Alan A. Freeman|the Gaelic footballer|Alan Freeman (Gaelic footballer)}}
{{Use British English|date=March 2012}} [[File:Alan_Freeman.gif|thumb|right|Alan Freeman]] '''Alan Leslie "Fluff" Freeman''', [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (6 July 1927 – 27 November 2006) was an Australian-born British [[disc jockey]] and radio personality in the United Kingdom for 40 years, best known for presenting ''[[Pick of the Pops]] ''from 1961 to 2000.
==Career== Born and educated in New South Wales, Australia, Freeman worked as an assistant paymaster/accountant for one of Australia's largest timber companies after leaving school.
Freeman originally wanted to be an opera singer but decided his voice was not strong enough. He was invited to audition as a radio announcer in 1952 and commenced working for [[7LA]] in [[Tasmania]], known as the teenager's station. Freeman's duties included continuity announcer, presenter of musical programmes incorporating opera, ballet and classical music, DJ for the top 100, news reader, quiz master and commercials reader.
After moving to radio station [[3KZ]] in Melbourne, in 1957 he took a nine-month trip around the world, with the promise to return to Melbourne by January 1958. He arrived in London and on deciding to stay wrote numerous letters of delay and later apology, to his former employer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Aircheck Tracker<!-- Bot generated title --> |url=http://www.geocities.com/thehotw/AlanFreemantracker.htm |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kmFJAnST?url=http://www.geocities.com/thehotw/AlanFreemantracker.htm |archivedate=25 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
Freeman began his British career as a summer relief disc jockey on [[Radio Luxembourg (English)|Radio Luxembourg]] and continued to present late-evening programmes on the station until the early 1970s. He gained his nickname "Fluff" as a result of a fluffy jumper that he was fond of wearing.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/2940413.stm "Obituary: Alan 'Fluff' Freeman"], BBC News, 28 November 2006</ref>
In 1960 he moved to the [[BBC Light Programme]] as presenter of the ''Records Around Five'' show, which was introduced by his signature tune, "[[At the Sign of the Swingin' Cymbal]]", written by [[Brian Fahey (composer)|Brian Fahey]]. The more upbeat version performed by 'Brass Incorporated' was introduced in April 1970.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2006/nov/29/guardianobituaries.media|title=Obituary: Alan Freeman|author=Adam Sweeting|work=the Guardian}}</ref> In September 1961 he introduced ''[[Pick of the Pops]]'' as part of a Saturday evening show ''Trad Tavern''. ''Pick Of The Pops'' became a permanent show in its own right in 1962, with Freeman presenting it until 24 September 1972 and continuing with his 'Swingin' Cymbal' signature tune. At the same time, he was one of the original team of presenters of BBC TV's ''[[Top of the Pops]]'', a regular member of the ''[[Juke Box Jury]]'' panel and had a brief stint as compere of the lunchtime pop music show ''[[Go Man Go]]'' on the [[BBC Light Programme]] in 1963. In 1968 he presented a music magazine-style television show for the BBC, ''All Systems Freeman'', which aired for several weeks on Friday evening, but despite good reviews did not return for a second series.
In 1962 he recorded a dance single, "Madison Time", with the Talmy Stone Band. Released by [[Decca Records]], F11523, it was reportedly one of the label's worst-ever sellers.{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}}
In April 1972, Freeman joined the daily presenters on [[BBC Radio 1|Radio 1]], taking over the 3–5 p.m. show from [[Terry Wogan]]. He used "[[Soul Bossa Nova]]" by [[Quincy Jones]] as his theme until 1 June 1973. During this time he spotlighted youth clubs and young people and became Vice-President of the [[London Association of Youth Clubs]]. During the 1970s he also presented the Radio 1 series ''Quiz Kid'' on Sunday evenings, which was recorded at youth clubs and boys' clubs all over the country; while on Saturday afternoons he presented his ''Rock Show'', featuring heavy and progressive rock and a rundown of the album chart, from 30 June 1973 to 26 August 1978. He presented the original version of ''The Story of Pop'' as a 26-part Radio 1 series in 1973–74. From 1975 to 1977, Freeman presented the Radio 2 musical game show ''Free Spin''. In addition he lent his name to several rock and classical compilation albums, the best-known being "By Invitation Only" (1976), a collection of material sourced from artists on the [[Atlantic]] label.<ref>{{cite book | first= John| last= Van der Kiste| year= 2016| title= Pop Pickers and Music Vendors| publisher= Fonthill Media| location= Stroud| isbn= | page= }}</ref>
Freeman left the BBC to work for [[Capital London|Capital Radio]] from 1979 to 1988, presenting the Top 40 of the 70s, on 31 December 1979. He later revived ''Pick of the Pops'' on 13 March 1982 (now called ''Pick of the Pops Take Two'', combining the current Top 15 with an earlier chart) and ''The Rock Show'' previous to that on 7 January 1980. He returned to the BBC and Radio 1 in January 1989 to revive ''The Rock Show'' and ''Pick of the Pops''. This run of ''Pick of the Pops'' ended on 27 December 1992 but he continued to host ''The Rock Show'' until 23 October 1993, when he, with other long-serving DJs, left the station as it was revamped by controller [[Matthew Bannister]]. In 1990, he appeared as a celebrity guest on the television series [[You Bet!]], made by [[London Weekend Television]] and hosted by Sir [[Bruce Forsyth]]. He was the subject of ''[[This Is Your Life (UK TV series)|This Is Your Life]]'' in 1987 when he was surprised by [[Eamonn Andrews]].
In December 1993, he presented the ''Alternative Chart Show'' on a trial one-off [[Restricted Service Licence]] (RSL) broadcast by [[XFM]] in [[London]]. Throughout 1994 he presented a revised and expanded version of the Radio 1 series ''The Story of Pop'', broadcast in 52 hour-long episodes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://epguides.com/StoryofPop/ |title=Epguides |publisher=Epguides.com |accessdate=4 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120628210836/http://epguides.com/StoryofPop/ |archivedate=28 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> He then hosted ''Pick of the Pops Take Three'' on [[Gold (radio)|Capital Gold]] from April 1994 until January 1997. In 1996 and 1997 he also hosted ''The Friday Rock Show'' on [[Virgin Radio]] and was heard presenting one-off shows on [[Classic FM (UK)|Classic FM]].
In 1998 he was awarded the [[MBE]] for services to broadcasting.
He returned to the BBC on [[BBC Radio 2|Radio 2]], taking ''Pick of the Pops'' back to its home, from 1997 until 2000. A lifetime love of [[classical music]] and particularly [[opera]] was developed in the show ''Their Greatest Bits'', which resulted in another compilation CD on the [[BBC Records|BBC]] label. Throughout his career, he was well-known especially for his jingles, which integrated short bursts of classical music and hard rock segued together, as well as his catchphrases, including 'Hi there, pop pickers!', which later became 'Greetings, music lovers!' on his classical shows, and 'All right?', right, stay bright' and frequently 'Not arf!'<ref>{{cite book | first= John| last= Van der Kiste| year= 2016| title= Pop Pickers and Music Vendors| publisher= Fonthill Media| location= Stroud| isbn= | page= }}</ref>
As [[arthritis]] got the better of his hands, he handed ''Pick of the Pops'' over to ex-[[96 Trent FM|Radio Trent]] DJ [[Dale Winton]] who hosted it until 2010.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/683704.stm | work=BBC News | title=Fluff's farewell to pop pickers | date=20 March 2000 | accessdate=23 April 2010}}</ref>
=== Acting === Freeman acted in the horror film ''[[Dr. Terror's House of Horrors]]'' (1965) and the rock musical ''[[Absolute Beginners (film)|Absolute Beginners]]'' (1986), and played himself or a similar character in films such as ''[[It's Trad, Dad!]]'' (1962), ''[[Just for Fun (film)|Just for Fun]]'' (1963) and ''[[Sebastian (1968 film)|Sebastian]]'' (1968). He also played God (albeit a God who sat at a [[mixing desk]] and said "Alright?") in two episodes of ''[[The Young Ones (TV series)|The Young Ones]]'' in 1984. Freeman also appeared in TV advertisements for Brentford Nylons and for [[Omo (detergent)|Omo]] "with exclusive WM7 for perfect whiteness."
=== Recognition === Freeman's style has been parodied, and he was the model for [[Harry Enfield]]'s character [[Smashie and Nicey|Dave Nice]], although he contributed to the [[satire]] himself in good grace by appearing on Enfield's show (and Enfield himself praised Freeman in [[Simon Garfield]]'s book on Radio 1, ''The Nation's Favourite'', by categorising him along with [[John Peel]] as "DJs who loved music" as opposed to "DJs who loved the sound of their own voices, like [[Dave Lee Travis]]").
For all Freeman's supposed [[clichés]] and [[archetype]]s in his broadcasting style, he has been regarded as original by fellow broadcasters. When he appeared on [[John Peel]]'s ''[[This Is Your Life]]'', Peel said: "Fluff is the greatest out-and-out disc jockey of them all".
After Freeman's death, [[Robin Gibb]] wrote a tribute "[[Alan Freeman Days]]".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.robingibb.com/news/2008/05/15/alan_freeman_days|title=Alan Freeman Days|last=|first=|date=15 May 2008|website=robingibb.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080619083555/http://www.robingibb.com/news/2008/05/15/alan_freeman_days|archive-date=19 June 2008|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref> Recorded in August 2007, the song was included on Gibb's first posthumous album ''[[50 St. Catherine's Drive]]'' in 2014.
==Honours== He was appointed [[Member of the Order of the British Empire]] (MBE) in 1998. In May 2000 he was presented with a Lifetime Achievement award at the [[Sony Radio Academy Awards]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/733968.stm | work=BBC News | title=Not arf! Awards glory for Fluff | date=3 May 2000 | accessdate=23 April 2010}}</ref> In 1976 he was initiated into the [[Grand Order of Water Rats]], and ten years later was elected "King Rat".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gowr.co.uk/all-water-rats/v/142|title=Biography of a Water Rat|publisher=}}</ref>
==Personal life==
In March 1994, Freeman revealed on breakfast television that he had become [[Celibacy|celibate]] in 1981 but had been [[bisexuality|bisexual]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://knittingcircle.org.uk/alanfreeman.html|title=Knitting Circle|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070817010145/http://www.knittingcircle.org.uk/alanfreeman.html|archivedate=17 August 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He was memorably described by [[Graham Chapman]] as being "keen on motor bikes and leather and men".<ref>Michael Palin: "Diaries 1969–1979" p. 290</ref>
In later years, Freeman suffered from [[arthritis]] and [[asthma]] (from a 60-a-day [[tobacco smoking|smoking]] habit) and used a [[Zimmer frame]]. He lived at [[Brinsworth House]], a retirement home for actors and performers run by the [[Entertainment Artistes' Benevolent Fund]] in Twickenham, until his death.
==Death== He died aged 79 on 27 November 2006 in [[Brinsworth House]], after a short illness.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=166927 |title=Australian and World News - ninemsn, Nine News |work=news |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120211095922/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=166927 |archivedate=11 February 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> His funeral took place on 7 December 2006, at South West Middlesex Crematorium and was attended by DJs including future ''Pick of the Pops'' host [[Paul Gambaccini]], [[Dave Lee Travis]], [[Nicky Campbell]], and his Radio One Top 40 successors [[Wes Butters]], [[Simon Bates]] and [[Richard Skinner (broadcaster)|Richard Skinner]].
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{IMDb name|0293283}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060830192757/http://www.radioacademy.org/halloffame/freeman_a/index.shtml Bio and citation at the Radio Academy] * [http://www.radiorewind.co.uk/radio1/alan_freeman_page.htm Bio at RadioRewind.co.uk] including a rare interview with [[Nathan Morley]] * [http://www.bigredbook.info/alan_freeman.html Alan Freeman's appearance on This Is Your Life]
===Obituaries=== * Broadsheet ** [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,60-2476690,00.html Times obituary] – [[The Times]] ** [https://www.theguardian.com/obituaries/story/0,,1959272,00.html Guardian obituary] – [[The Guardian]] ** [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/11/29/db2901.xml&DCMP=EMC-new_29112006 Telegraph obituary] – [[Daily Telegraph]] ** [https://web.archive.org/web/20070930190407/http://news.independent.co.uk/people/obituaries/article2023805.ece The Independent] – [[The Independent]] * Tabloid ** [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/showbiz/showbiznews.html?in_article_id=419196&in_page_id=1773 Daily Mail obituary] – [[Daily Mail]] ** [https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/tm_headline=fluff-of-legend%26method=full%26objectid=18175881%26siteid=94762-name_page.html Mirror obituary] – [[The Daily Mirror]] ** [http://www.thesun.co.uk/article/0,,2-2006550430,00.html ''The Sun'' obituary] – ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]''

revision.text:
{{Infobox European Parliament constituency |title = Bedfordshire |map = Image:Europarl logo.svg |mapcaption = [[European Parliament]] logo |created = 1979 |dissolved = 1984 |meps = 1 |memberstate = United Kingdom |sources = [http://www.election.demon.co.uk/] }} '''Bedfordshire''' was a [[European Parliament constituency|constituency]] of the [[European Parliament]] located in the [[United Kingdom]], electing one [[Member of the European Parliament]] by the [[first-past-the-post]] electoral system. Created in [[European Parliament election, 1979 (United Kingdom)|1979]] for the first elections to the European Parliament, it was abolished in 1984 and succeeded by [[Cambridge and Bedfordshire North (European Parliament constituency)|Cambridge and Bedfordshire North]] and [[Bedfordshire South (European Parliament constituency)|Bedfordshire South]]. ==Boundaries== It consisted of the [[List of United Kingdom Parliament constituencies|parliamentary constituencies]] of [[Bedford (UK Parliament constituency)|Bedford]], [[Mid Bedfordshire (UK Parliament constituency)|Mid Bedfordshire]], [[South Bedfordshire (UK Parliament constituency)|South Bedfordshire]], [[Hemel Hempstead (UK Parliament constituency)|Hemel Hempstead]], [[Hitchin (UK Parliament constituency)|Hitchin]], [[Luton East (UK Parliament constituency)|Luton East]], and [[Luton West (UK Parliament constituency)|Luton West]].[[Boundary Commission for England]], ''European Assembly Constituencies'', December 1978. When it was abolished in 1984, the subsequent seats were based on the parliamentary constituencies created by the 1983 boundary changes. The area covered by the new parliamentary constituencies of Mid Bedfordshire and [[North Bedfordshire (UK Parliament constituency)|North Bedfordshire]] became part of the [[Cambridge and Bedfordshire North (European Parliament constituency)|Cambridge and Bedfordshire North]] constituency, while the new constituencies of [[South West Bedfordshire (UK Parliament constituency)|South West Bedfordshire]], [[Stevenage (UK Parliament constituency)|Stevenage]], [[West Hertfordshire (UK Parliament constituency)|West Hertfordshire]], [[Luton North (UK Parliament constituency)|Luton North]] and [[Luton South (UK Parliament constituency)|Luton South]] were transferred to [[Bedfordshire South (European Parliament constituency)|Bedfordshire South]].European Parliament Information Office, ''MEPs and their constituencies'', December 1988 ==MEPs== {| class="wikitable" |- !colspan="2"|Election!!Member!!Party |- |style="background-color: {{Conservative Party (UK)/meta/color}}" | | [[European Parliament election, 1979 (United Kingdom)|1979]] | [[Peter Beazley]] | [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] |- | colspan="2" align="center" | [[European Parliament election, 1984 (United Kingdom)|1984]] | colspan="2" | ''constituency abolished, see [[Cambridge and Bedfordshire North (European Parliament constituency)|Cambridge and Bedfordshire North]] and [[Bedfordshire South (European Parliament constituency)|Bedfordshire South]]'' |} ==Elections== {{Election box begin| |title=[[European Parliament election, 1979 (United Kingdom)]]: Bedfordshire''European Parliament election 1979 : United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland : results of the European election on 7 June 1979'', Luxembourg: European Parliament, October 1983{{cite web|url=http://www.election.demon.co.uk/epe1.html|title=United Kingdom European Parliamentary Election results 1979-99: England|website=Election.demon.co.uk|accessdate=7 November 2018}} }} {{Election box candidate with party link| |party = Conservative Party (UK) |candidate = [[Peter Beazley|Peter George Beazley]] |votes = 102,054 |percentage = 58.8 |change = ''N/A'' }} {{Election box candidate (2011) | Next single = | Misc = {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Croatia}} "Celebrate" | image = | caption = | year = 2011 | country = Croatia | artist = [[Daria Kinzer|Daria]] | as = | with = | language = | languages = English | composer = [[Boris Đurđević]] | lyricist = [[Boris Đurđević]], [[Marina Mudrinić]] | place = | points = | place_semi = 15th | points_semi = 41 | prev = Lako je sve | prev_link = Lako je sve | next = Nebo | next_link = Nebo (Nina Badrić song) }} }} "'''Celebrate'''" (previously "'''Break a Leg'''") is a song by Croatian female singer [[Daria Kinzer|Daria]], written by Croatian [[Composer|song composer]] [[Boris Đurđević]]. revision.text:
{{Infobox museum |name = Dublinia |native_name = |logo = |image = File:Dublinia, Dublin, Southeast View 20150808 1.jpg |caption = Synod hall, the building that houses Dublinia |established = 1993 |location = 14 Henrietta Street,
[[Dublin]], Ireland |type = [[Vikings]] |visitors = |coordinates = {{Coord|53.343333|N|6.272222|W|display=inline,title}} |director = |map_type = Ireland Central Dublin |curator = |publictransit = |website = {{URL|dublinia.ie}} }} [[File:Viking burial scene, Dublinia.jpg|thumb|left|[[Viking]] burial scene, Dublinia]] '''Dublinia''' is a historical recreation (or [[living history]]) museum and visitor attraction in [[Dublin]], [[Ireland]], focusing on the [[Viking]] and [[Medieval]] history of the city. Dublinia is located in a part of Dublin's [[Christ Church Cathedral, Dublin|Christ Church Cathedral]], known as the [[Christ Church Cathedral, Dublin#Synod hall and bridge|Synod hall]]. Dublinia features [[historical reenactment]], with actors playing the roles of Vikings and Medieval Dubliners (in full costume) and encourages visitors to join in. It has recreations of Viking and Medieval era buildings (houses, etc) and street scenes.[http://www.dublinia.ie/exhibitions_dublin-page.html Dublinia - Exhibitions] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120719075004/http://www.dublinia.ie/exhibitions_dublin-page.html |date=July 19, 2012 }} The exhibition was opened in 1993,{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/vikings-invade-for-the-return-of-dublinia-2177967.html|title=Vikings invade for the return of Dublinia|date=May 13, 2010|accessdate=10 November 2012|author=Michael McHale|work=[[Irish Independent]]}} and was redeveloped in 2010 at a cost of €2 million. The museum attracts over 125,000 visitors per annum.{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0512/breaking72.html|title=Dublinia unveils its €2m facelift|date=5 May 2010|accessdate=10 November 2012|work=[[Irish Times]]{{Subscription required|date=February 2014}}}} ==See also== * [[History of Dublin]] * [[Early Scandinavian Dublin]] * [[Jorvik Viking Centre]] (similar attraction in [[York]]) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official Website|dublinia.ie}} {{Museums and galleries in the Republic of Ireland by province|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Museums in Dublin (city)]] [[Category:Viking Age museums]] [[Category:1993 establishments in Ireland]] [[Category:Museums established in 1993]] {{Ireland-stub}}

Photo by Tristán White.]] '''"Et Cetera"''' is a song by [[Republic of Ireland|Irish]] singer [[Sinéad Mulvey]] and rock band [[Black Daisy]] that represented [[Ireland in the Eurovision Song Contest 2009|Ireland]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2009]] in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]]. The song was composed by a multinational songwriting team of Niall Mooney of Ireland, [[Jonas Gladnikoff]] of [[Sweden]], [http://www.danielemoretti.it/home.htm?lingua=en/ Daniele Moretti] of [[Italy]] and Christina Schilling of [[Denmark]].{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5177|title=Et Cetera wins Irish national final|last=Fisher|first=Luke|date=2009-02-20|publisher=''Oikotimes''|accessdate=2009-02-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224144116/http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5177|archivedate=2009-02-24|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13315|title=Ireland: Sinead Mulvey & Black Daisy to Eurovision|last=Klier|first=Marcus|date=2009-02-20|publisher=''ESCToday''|accessdate=2009-02-20}} The song competed in the second semi-final on 14 May 2009 but failed to qualify for the final, making it the second time in a row and the third time in 5 years the nation failed to make it to the final. It was chosen on 20 February 2009 as part of [[The Late Late Show (season 47)|a special edition]] of chat show ''[[The Late Late Show (Ireland)|The Late Late Show]]'' which had [[Jerry Springer]], [[Marty Whelan]] and [[Linda Martin]] reviewing the six entries competing to go to Moscow. It won with 78 points from a possible 80, awarded in two phases, phase one by national juries and phase two by the viewers. The song was released as a single by [[Sony BMG]] on 1 May in Ireland, as both a physical CD single and as a digital download.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13833|title=Ireland: Sony snap up Sinead|last=Darby|first=Harry|date=2009-04-29|publisher=''ESCToday''|accessdate=2009-05-02}} It debuted on the Irish charts at #15 and peaked at #6.[http://acharts.us/song/43494 Irish Singles Chart] Accessed May 16, 2009. ==Track listings== # "Et Cetera" - 2:59 # "Et Cetera" (Extravaganza Mix) - 3:31 # "Et Cetera" (Instrumental) - 3:00 ==Charts== {| class="wikitable" !align="left"|Chart (2009) !align="left"|Peak
position |- |align="left"|[[Irish Singles Chart]][http://acharts.us/song/43494 Irish Singles Chart] |align="center"|6 |- |} ==See also== * [[Ireland in the Eurovision Song Contest 2009]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 2009}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of 2009]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of Ireland]] [[Category:Songs written by Jonas Gladnikoff]] [[Category:Sony BMG singles]] [[Category:2008 songs]] {{2000s-song-stub}} {{Ireland-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Ev iyesi''' ({{lang-tt|Öy İyäse}} or {{lang|tt|Öy Atası}}, sometimes ''Өй бәкчәсе'' "House Guard") is a [[household deity]] in [[Turkish mythology]]. Also known as '''Uy (Oy) iyesi''' or '''Yurt iyesi'''.
Ev iyesi is a deity or spirit that protects the home, looking after the entire household or certain key members.
==Meaning of iye== Ev İyesi is a house spirit in Turkish / Turkic folklore. Usually İye has the meaning of "[[familiar spirit]]". He is masculine, typically small and bearded. He takes on the appearance of current or former owners of the house and have a grey beard. In Anatolia he is known as ''Sahab'' or ''Kimsene''.
===In Turkish Folklore=== Traditionally, every house is said to have its ''iye''. The word "''iye''" means owner, master, possessor, etc. It does not do evil unless angered by a family’s poor keep of the household, profane language or neglect. He is seen as the home's guardian, and he sometimes helps with household chores and field work. Some even treat them as part of the family, albeit an unseen one, and leave them gifts like milk in the kitchen overnight. It is said the favorite place for these spirits to live is either the threshold under the door or under the stove. The center of the house is also said to be their domain. Ev İyesi maintains peace and order, and rewards a well-maintained household. Some peasants feed him nightly in return for protection of their house. When a new house was built, Anatolian people would attract the İye to take to the new house.
==Similar creatures== # '''Eşik iyesi''' or '''Astana iyesi''' (Spirit of doorstep) is a some kind of Ev iyesi. Even they are synonymous. It lives on the threshold (doorstone) of the house. # '''Mutfak iyesi''' or '''Aşlık İyesi''' lives in kitchen. # '''Evlik İyesi''' or '''Ambar İyesi''' is the protector spirit of cellar or larder.
==See also== * [[Domovoi]]
== External links == * [http://www.kayipdunya.com/wp-content/uploads/kalins-pdf/singles/turk-mitolojisi-sozlugu-e-g.pdf Turkish Mythology Glossary (Türk Mitoloji Sözlüğü), Pınar Karaca] (Ev İyesi) * [http://turkoloji.cu.edu.tr/HALKBILIM/culpan_zaripova_cetin_tatar_turkleri_mitoloji.pdf Tatar Mitolojisinde Varlıklar, Çulpan Zaripova] (Öy, Yort İyäse, Ev İyesi)
==Bibliography== * Türk Söylence Sözlüğü (Turkish Mythological Dictionary), Deniz Karakurt, [[:tr:Türk Söylence Sözlüğü|(OTRS: CC BY-SA 3.0)]] {{tr}} * Türk Mitolojisi Ansiklopedik Sözlük, Celal Beydili, Yurt Yayınevi {{tr}} * Bayazitova, Flöra (1995), Tatar Halqınıñ Bäyräm Häm Könküreş Yolaları, Qazan: Tatarstan Kitap Näşriyatı {{tt icon}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ev Iyesi}} [[Category:Turkish folklore]] [[Category:Turkish words and phrases]] [[Category:Turkic legendary creatures]] [[Category:Turkic deities]]

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat IVA F-6 | image = INTELSAT IVA.jpg | image_size = 160px | image_caption = Intelsat IVA F-6
| mission_type = [[Communications]] | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 1978-035A<ref>[[NASA]] [[Goddard Space Flight Center]]. [http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1978-035A INTELSAT 4A F-6]. ''NSSDC Master Catalog''. Retrieved April 22, 2017.</ref> | SATCAT = 10778<ref>[http://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=10778 INTELSAT 4A-F6] ''N2yo.com''. Retrieved April 22, 2017.</ref> | mission_duration = 7 years design life
| spacecraft_bus = [[Spacebus|HS-353]] | manufacturer = [[Hughes Space and Communications]] | BOL_mass = {{convert|825|kg}} | dry_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|1,515|kg}} | power =
| launch_date = {{start-date|March 31, 1978, 23:36:01|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Atlas-Centaur|Atlas SLV-3D Centaur-D1AR]] | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 36|LC-36B]] | launch_contractor = [[NASA]] | entered_service =
| disposal_type = Decommissioned | deactivated =
| orbit_epoch = March 31, 1978 | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|549|km|mi|sp=us}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|35,949|km|mi|sp=us}} | orbit_inclination = 21.8° | orbit_eccentricity = 0.71872 | orbit_period = 641 minutes | orbit_longitude = | apsis = gee
| trans_band = 20 [[IEEE]] [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]] (NATO [[G band (NATO)|G]]/[[H band (NATO)|H-band]]) | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW =
| programme = ''Intelsat IVA'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat IVA F-5]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat V F-1]] (Intelsat V) }} '''Intelsat IVA F-6''' was a [[geostationary]] [[communication]] [[satellite]] built by [[Hughes Aircraft Company|Hughes]], it was owned by [[Intelsat]]. The satellite was based on the [[Spacebus|HS-353]] platform and its estimated useful life was 7 years.
== History == The Intelsat IVA F-6 was part of the Intelsat IVA series which consisted of 6 satellites, of which five were successfully placed into orbit. All five satellites in the series were retired and operated an average of almost 4 years beyond their life expectancies. The satellite antenna allowed coverage from the land masses on both sides of the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] basin with four point beams and had sufficient insulation between the east beams and the western beams that used the same frequencies in the east and west. The separation of the beam by directional [[Antenna (radio)|antenna]] allowed this dual use of the frequency, significantly increasing the capacity of satellite communication within an assigned frequency range. Although the initial requirement Intelsat VAT series was only for the Atlantic service, but also was given special attention during the project to provide service on the [[Indian Ocean]] and [[Pacific Ocean]].
The satellite had 20 transponders (individual radio transmitters) compared to 12 on board each Intelsat IV satellite. It had a total height of 22 feet, 11 inches (7.01 meters) and a diameter of 7 feet, 9 inches (2.38 meters). The solar panels, covered with about 17,000 solar cells, provided primary energy of 600 Watts. The weight of the satellite, which had an orbiting life project of 7 years, was about £3335 (1,515 kg).
The satellite was successfully launched into space on March 31, 1978, by means of an [[Atlas-Centaur]] vehicle from the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]], [[United States]]. It had a launch mass of 1,515 kg.<ref>Krebs, Gunter. [http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/intelsat-4a.htm Intelsat-4A]. ''Gunter's Space Page''. Retrieved 22 April 2017.</ref>
== See also == * [[Intelsat]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
{{Orbital launches in 1978}} {{Intelsat}}

revision.text:
The '''International Advisory and Monitoring Board''' was appointed to oversee the [[Coalition Provisional Authority]]'s disbursements from the [[humanitarian]] [[Development Fund for Iraq]]. When the CPA was authorized to manage the DFI by [[United Nations]] [[United Nations resolution|resolution]] [[UN Security Council Resolution 1483|1483]]. the CPA was obliged to cooperate with the oversight of the IAMB. The IAMB was composed of senior representatives from the United Nations, the [[Arab Fund for Social and Economic Development]], the [[International Monetary Fund]], and the [[World Bank]].
The IAMB had trouble getting co-operation from the [[Civilian Administrator of Iraq|Administrator of Iraq]], [[Paul Bremer]], and from the CPA. In their final press release before the CPA's authority expired the IAMB wrote:
:''"The IAMB regrets, despite its repeated requests, the delay in receiving reports on audits undertaken by various agencies on sole-sourced contracts funded by the DFI. In the light of these delays the IAMB decided to commission a special audit to determine the extent of sole-sourced contracts. The IAMB was also informed by the CPA that '''contrary to earlier representations''' the award of metering contracts have been delayed and continues to urge the expeditious resolution of this critical issue. Finally, the IAMB noted the delay in completing the audits on the [[State Oil Marketing Organization]] (SOMO) and requested the CPA to press for prompt finalization of these."''
==See also== *[[Coalition Provisional Authority]] *[[Coalition Provisional Authority Program Review Board]] *[[Development Fund for Iraq]] *[[KPMG audit of the Development Fund for Iraq]]
==External links==
*[http://www.iamb.info/ The IAMB website]. *[http://today.reuters.co.uk/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=worldNews&storyID=2005-06-21T025708Z_01_MOL110362_RTRUKOC_0_IRAQ-UN-CONTRACTS.xml U.N. looking into Iraq's handling of goods contracts]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''[[Reuters]], June 22, 2005'' *[https://www.theguardian.com/Iraq/Story/0,2763,1522983,00.html So, Mr Bremer, where did all the money go?], ''[[The Guardian]]'', July 7, 2005 *[http://www.chron.com/cs/CDA/ssistory.mpl/world/3440238 U.S. should repay millions to Iraq, audit board says: U.N. group says it owes nation for contracting work assigned to KBR], ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' reprint of ''[[New York Times]]'', November 5, 2005

page.title: International Year for the Culture of Peace

revision.comment: Fix date
revision.text:
'''The International Year for the Culture of Peace''' was designated by the [[United Nations]] as the year 2000, with the aim of celebrating and encouraging a culture of [[peace]].
== Origins ==
Since 1959 the [[United Nations]] has designated specific years to emphasize issues which are part of the mission of the organization. The International Year for the Culture of Peace was proclaimed in a [[United Nations General Assembly]] resolution in 1997 on the basis of an [[United Nations Economic and Social Council|Economic and Social Council]] resolution.<ref name="UN_ARES5215">{{UN document |docid=A-RES-52-15 |type=Resolution |body=General Assembly |session=52 |accessdate=2007-08-10 |date=20 November 1997}}</ref> The General Assembly invited a '''Declaration and Programme of Action''' from UNESCO and adopted it after ten months of difficult negotiation.<ref name="UN_ARES53243">{{UN document |docid=A-RES-53-243 |type=Resolution |body=General Assembly |session=53 |accessdate=2007-08-10 |date=13 September 1999}}</ref>
== The IYCP Taskforce ==
The lead organization for the International Year was [[UNESCO]]. There was a logic to this, in that [[UNESCO]] is the [[United Nations]] organization dealing with education, and also in that the constitutional mandate of [[UNESCO]] involves the encouragement of a global culture of peace. Within the [[UNESCO]] Secretariat in Paris, a specific International Year for the Culture of Peace Taskforce was established from 1998 to 2000, with the aim of co-ordinating the activities to publicize the International Year. Members of the Taskforce included: [[David Adams (peace activist)|David Adams]] (Chair)<ref>http://www.culture-of-peace.info/adams.html, accessed 24 October 2009</ref>, Enzo Fazzino, Katherine Stoessel,<ref name="culture-of-peace.info">http://www.culture-of-peace.info/history/page32.html, accessed 24 October 2009</ref> Di Bretherton<ref name="culture-of-peace.info"/>, Zeynep Varoglu<ref name="culture-of-peace.info"/> and Jan Visser.<ref name="culture-of-peace.info"/>
== International Year Strategies and Results ==
The strategies behind the International Year centred upon involving civil society as much as possible. The specific initiatives included the collection of some 75 million signatures worldwide in support of a culture of peace, with the Manifesto 2000 Project.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://decade-culture-of-peace.org/iycp/iycp-uk/uk_sum_monde.htm| title=World Information Board| publisher=Website for Culture of Peace Decade| accessdate=2018-09-18}}</ref> Another initiative was the [[Culture of Peace News Network]], otherwise known as the [[CPNN]], a web-based news service reporting news in support of a culture of peace.
An extensive description of the results obtained during the International Year was published by UNESCO.<ref>http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0012/001223/122350e.pdf REPORT ON THE PROGRESS MADE BY UNESCO IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROGRAMME OF ACTION ON A CULTURE OF PEACE</ref>
== Assessment of the International Year ==
Opinion is divided as to how effective the International Year was. It is possible to argue that there was much rhetoric in the International Year, and yet often the impact of such events can only be discerned many years later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eprints.qut.edu.au/archive/00002945/| title=Page, James S. (2001) 'The International Year for the Culture of Peace: Was It Worthwhile?'. ''International Journal of Cultural Studies''. 4(3): 348-351}}</ref>
== Ongoing Commitment of the United Nations ==
The work of supporting and encouraging a culture of peace continues through the [[International Decade for the Promotion of a Culture of Peace and Non-Violence for the Children of the World]], and the ongoing [[Culture of Peace News Network]].
==See also==
*[[The Ribbon International]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.culture-of-peace.info/history/introduction.html Adams, David (2003) 'Early History of the Culture of Peace: A Personal Memoire'] *[http://eprints.qut.edu.au/archive/00002945/ Page, James S. (2001) 'The International Year for the Culture of Peace: Was It Worthwhile?'. ''International Journal of Cultural Studies''. 4(3): 348-351] *[http://cpnn-world.org/ Culture of Peace News Network]
{{UN International Years}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:International Year For The Culture Of Peace}} [[Category:United Nations observances|Peace, International Year for the Culture of]] [[Category:2000]] [[Category:2000 in international relations]] [[Category:United Nations peacekeeping]]

page.title: List of regional and minority parties in Europe

revision.comment: update, PDeCAT has been expelled from ALDE
revision.text:
This is a '''list of regional and minority parties in Europe'''. Most of them are [[regionalism (politics)|regionalist]], some are [[autonomism (political doctrine)|autonomist]] or [[separatism|separatist]], others represent [[minority group|minority]] interests. To be included in the list, parties need to gain at least 3.0% at the country-level or 3.0% in regional entities with at least 500,000 inhabitants or 6.0% in those with at least 100,000 inhabitants. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left;font-size:85%" |- !Country || Party || Region / constituency || Electoral results || European party† = Observer or associate member |- |{{flag|Austria}} || [[Team Carinthia]] || {{flag|Carinthia}} || [[Carinthia]] [[Carinthian state election, 2018|2018]]: 5.7% || none |- |{{flag|Austria}} || [[Free Party Salzburg]] || {{flag|Salzburg}} || [[Salzburg (state)|Salzburg]] [[Salzburg state election, 2018|2018]]: 4.5% || none |- |{{flag|Austria}} || [[Citizens' Forum Austria|Citizens' Forum Tyrol]] || {{flag|Tyrol}} || [[Tyrol (state)|Tyrol]] [[Tyrolean state election, 2018|2018]]: 5.5% || none |- |{{flag|Belgium}} || [[New Flemish Alliance]] || {{flag|Flanders}} || [[Belgium]] [[Belgian federal election, 2014|2014]]: 20.3%

| image_map = EU-Lithuania.svg | alt_map = Locator map of Lithuania | map_caption = {{map_caption |location_color=dark green |region=Europe |region_color=dark grey |subregion=the European Union |subregion_color=green |legend=EU-Lithuania.svg}} | image_map2=Lithuania in the world (W3).svg | map_caption2=Location of Lithuania in the World | capital = [[Vilnius]] | coordinates = {{Coord|54|41|N|25|19|E|type:city}} | largest_city = capital | official_languages = [[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]] | ethnic_groups = {{unbulleted list | 86.7% [[Lithuanians]] | 5.6% [[Poles]] | 4.8% [[Russians]] | 1.3% [[Belarusians]] | 0.7% [[Ukrainians]] | 0.9% [[Ethnic minorities in Lithuania|other]] }} | ethnic_groups_year = 2015{{cite web |url=http://alkas.lt/2015/12/16/a-butkus-lietuvos-gyventojai-tautybes-poziuriu/ |title=Lietuvos gyventojų tautinė sudėtis 2014–2015 m. |website=Alkas.lt|accessdate=6 October 2017}} | demonym = [[Lithuanians|Lithuanian]] | government_type = [[Unitary state|Unitary]] [[semi-presidential]] [[republic]]{{cite book |last=Kulikauskienė |first=Lina |date=2002 |title=Lietuvos Respublikos Konstitucija |trans-title=The Constitution of the Republic of Lithuania |url= |language=Lithuanian |location= |publisher=Native History, CD. |isbn=9986-9216-7-8 |quote= }}{{cite journal |last=Veser |first=Ernst |author-link= |date=23 September 1997 |title=Semi-Presidentialism-Duverger's Concept — A New Political System Model |url=http://www.rchss.sinica.edu.tw/publication/ebook/journal/11-01-1999/11_1_2.pdf |publisher=Department of Education, School of Education, [[University of Cologne]] |location= |language=English, Chinese |pages=39–60 |access-date=23 August 2017 |quote=Duhamel has developed the approach further: He stresses that the French construction does not correspond to either parliamentary or the presidential form of government, and then develops the distinction of 'système politique' and 'régime constitutionnel'. While the former comprises the exercise of power that results from the dominant institutional practice, the latter is the totality of the rules for the dominant institutional practice of the power. In this way, France appears as 'presidentialist system' endowed with a 'semi-presidential regime' (1983: 587). By this standard he recognizes Duverger's ''pléiade'' as semi-presidential regimes, as well as Poland, Romania, Bulgaria and Lithuania (1993: 87). }}{{cite journal |last=Shugart |first=Matthew Søberg |author-link=Matthew Søberg Shugart |date=September 2005 |title=Semi-Presidential Systems: Dual Executive and Mixed Authority Patterns |url=http://dss.ucsd.edu/~mshugart/semi-presidentialism.pdf |dead-url=yes |journal=Graduate School of International Relations and Pacific Studies |location=United States |publisher=University of California, San Diego |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080819200307/http://dss.ucsd.edu/~mshugart/semi-presidentialism.pdf |archive-date=19 August 2008 |access-date=23 August 2017 |ref=harv |postscript=. }}{{cite journal |last=Shugart |first=Matthew Søberg |author-link=Matthew Søberg Shugart |date=December 2005 |title=Semi-Presidential Systems: Dual Executive And Mixed Authority Patterns |url=http://www.palgrave-journals.com/fp/journal/v3/n3/pdf/8200087a.pdf |journal=French Politics |publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]] Journals |volume=3 |issue=3 |pages=323–351 |doi=10.1057/palgrave.fp.8200087 |doi-access=free |access-date=23 August 2017 |quote=A pattern similar to the French case of compatible majorities alternating with periods of cohabitation emerged in Lithuania, where Talat-Kelpsa (2001) notes that the ability of the Lithuanian president to influence government formation and policy declined abruptly when he lost the sympathetic majority in parliament. |ref=harv |postscript=. }} | leader_title1 = [[List of rulers of Lithuania|President]] | leader_name1 = [[Dalia Grybauskaitė]] | leader_title2 = [[Prime Minister of Lithuania|Prime
