{{distinguish|Miss Congo (RC)}} {{Infobox Organization |name = Miss Democratic Republic of the Congo |motto = |formation = 1968 |type = [[Beauty pageant]] |headquarters = [[Kinshasa]] |location = [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|DR Congo]] |membership = [[Miss Universe]]
[[Miss World]] |language = [[French language|French]] |leader_title = Organization |leader_name = |key_people = |num_staff = |budget = |website = [http://www.missrdcongo.cd/ missrdcongo.cd] }} '''Miss Congo (DRC)''' or '''Miss Democratic Republic of the Congo''' (''Formerly known as Miss Zaire'') is a national [[Beauty pageant]] in [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]]. ==History== Miss DRC began in 1968. The pageant was known as Miss Zaire until 1997. The pageant was sponsored by Ministry of Tourism in Kinshasa. The country has competed in the [[Miss Universe]], [[Miss World]], and [[Miss International]] competitions. Since 2009, the country does not exist to compete due to lack of funding and sponsorship. In 2016 Miss RD Congo Organization set new feature between Ministère du Tourisme, Pygma Communication as the production company. The pageant sets to be a reality TV show.{{cite news|title=Miss RD Congo is back after 4 years|publisher=kalimbaradio.com|url=http://blog.kalimbaradio.com/index.php/2016/07/06/miss-rd-congo-2016/|accessdate=4 September 2016}} ==Titleholders== ;Color key {{plainlist| * {{Color box|gold|border=darkgray}} Declared as Winner * {{Color box|#FFFF66|border=darkgray}} Ended as runner-up * {{Color box|#FFFACD|border=darkgray}} Ended as one of the finalists or semifinalists }} The winner of Miss Congo (DRC) might compete at the [[Miss Universe]], [[Miss World]] or other competitions. It depends on National pageant franchise holder to appoint the winner as official representative of the country. Nowadays, Democratic Republic of the Congo only competes in Miss World {| class="sortable" border="5" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #FFFFFF; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%; text-align:center" |- bgcolor="#787878" colspan=10 align="center" |width="60"|Year||width="250"|Miss RD Congo||width="250"|Notes||width="250"|Miss Universe RD Congo||width="250"|Miss World RD Congo |- | 2016 | Andrea Moloto | | - | Andréa Moloto |- | 2012 | Christelle Mbeni | {{n/a|Miss République Démocratique du Congo; Ministry of Tourism and Vodacom Congo & Pygma Communication Directorship}} | - | Christelle Mbeni
''Did not compete'' |- | 2008 | Kelly Falco | {{n/a|Miss Congo; Partnered to Beauties of Africa Inc.}} | - | Christelle Mbila |- | 2006 | Diane Mizuma | {{n/a|Miss World RD Congo 2006; Top 10 at Miss Tourism Queen International 2007}} | - | Diane Mizuma |- | 2005 | Nelly Dembo Osongo | {{n/a|Miss World RD Congo 2005; open casting}} | - | Nelly Dembo Osongo |- | 2004 | Norah Mpela | | - | - |- | 2000 | Florence Bandu | | - | - |- | 1994 | Grâce Nzeza Mwete | | - | - |- | 1989 | Lumeka Mulunge | | - | - |- | 1987 | Mesatewa Tuzolana | {{n/a|Miss International Zaire 1987}} | Mesatewa Tuzolana
''Did not compete'' | - |- | 1986 | Aimee Likobe Dobala | | style="background:#FFFACD;" |Aimee Likobe Dobala
'''Top 10''' | Aimee Likobe Dobala
''Did not compete'' |- | 1985 | Kayonga Mureka Tete | | style="background:#FFFF66;" |Kayonga Mureka Tete
'''Second Runner-up''' | style="background:#FFFACD;" |Kayonga Mureka Tete
'''Top 15 & Miss Photogenic''' |- | 1984 | Lokange Lwali | | Lokange Lwali | - |- | 1972 | Ombayi Mukuta | {{n/a|Miss Zaire Organization; wore a Zaire sash at Miss Universe history}} | Ombayi Mukuta
'''Miss Congeniality''' | - |- | 1971 | Martine Mualuke | | Martine Mualuke | - |- | 1970 | Marie-Josée Basoko | {{n/a|Miss Republic of Congo Organization; wore a Republic of Congo Sash at Miss Universe history}} | Marie-Josée Basoko | - |- | 1969 | Jeanne Mokomo | | Jeanne Mokomo | - |- | 1968 | Elizabeth Tavares | {{n/a|Miss Congo Beauty; a special guest of the organizing committee in Miss Europe 1968}} | Elizabeth Tavares | - |- |} ==See also== *[[Miss Congo (RC)]]Jeanne Mokomo miss Congo 1969 partticipated at Miss universe == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.missrdcongo.cd/ missrdcongo] *[https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCRx74FnlQhMYk6IwE0Uq_Lg Miss RD Congo - YouTube Channel] {{Miss Universe countries and territories}} {{Miss World countries and territories}} {{Miss International countries and territories}} [[Category:Miss Universe by country|Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Miss World by country|Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Miss International by country|Democratic Republic of the Congo]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1968]] {{DRCongo-stub}} {{Pageant-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Redirect|PEGI|the engineering company|Peninsula Engineering Group, Inc.}} {{EngvarB|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox organization |name = Pan European Game Information |image = PEGI - Logo.svg |image_border = |size = <!-- default 200 --> |alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> |caption = PEGI logo |abbreviation = PEGI |motto = |formation = {{start date and age|2003|4|9|df=y}} |extinction = <!-- date of extinction, optional --> |type = <!-- GO, NGO, IGO, INGO, etc --> |status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> |purpose = Video game classification |headquarters = |location = |coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> |region_served = Europe, Israel |membership = |language = <!-- official languages --> |leader_title = <!-- position title for the leader of the org --> |leader_name = <!-- name of leader --> |main_organ = <!-- gral. assembly, board of directors, etc --> |parent_organization = [[Interactive Software Federation of Europe]] |affiliations = <!-- if any --> |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = http://www.pegi.info |remarks = }}
'''Pan European Game Information''' ('''PEGI''') is a European [[video game content rating system]] established to help European consumers make informed decisions when buying video games or apps through the use of age recommendations and content descriptors. It was developed by the [[Interactive Software Federation of Europe]] (ISFE) and came into use in April 2003; it replaced many national age rating systems with a single European system. The PEGI system is now used in 38 countries and is based on a code of conduct, a set of rules to which every publisher using the PEGI system is contractually committed. PEGI self-regulation is composed by five age categories and eight content descriptors that advise the suitability and content of a game for a certain age range based on the games content.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pegi.info/en/ |title=PEGI Website |publisher=Pegi.info |date= |accessdate=29 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728144723/http://www.pegi.info/en/ |archive-date=28 July 2011 |dead-url=yes }}</ref> The age rating is not intended to indicate the difficulty of the game or the skill required to play it.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pegi.info/en/index/id/33 |title=PEGI Pan European Game Information – What do the labels mean? |publisher=Pegi.info |date= |accessdate=29 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807040750/http://www.pegi.info/en/index/id/33 |archive-date=7 August 2011 |dead-url=yes }}</ref>
== Age ratings == PEGI has five age categories. {| class="wikitable" ! Rating ! Description |- | [[File:PEGI 3.svg|60px]] | Suitable for all ages. Can contain non-sexual nudity. |- | [[File:PEGI 7.svg|60px]] | Suitable for persons 7 and older. Compared to PEGI 3, the game has to contain possibly frightening scenes or sounds. |- | [[File:PEGI 12.svg|60px]] | Suitable for persons 12 and older. Compared to PEGI 7, the game has to contain slightly graphic violence or non-graphic violence towards human-looking characters. |- | [[File:PEGI 16.svg|60px]] | Suitable for persons 16 and older. Compared to PEGI 12, the game has to contain realistic violence or sexual activity; or extreme bad language and depictions of tobacco/drug use or criminal activity. |- | [[File:PEGI 18.svg|60px]] | Suitable only for persons 18 and older. Compared to PEGI 16, the game has to contain very realistic and extreme violence that may be repulsive to players. |}
The current design was introduced at the end of 2009. Black and white icons were used until June 2009, when the colour-coded PEGI icons were announced, with green for 3 and 7, orange for 12 and 16, and red for 18. Plus signs were removed from the icons, and the background text changed from 'ISFE' from the old, black-and-white icons to 'PEGI' from the new, colour-coded PEGI icons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.next-gen.biz/news/pegi-unveils-new-ratings-symbols|date=17 June 2009|work=Edge|publisher=[[Future Publishing]]|title=PEGI Unveils New Ratings Symbols|author=Tom Ivan|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111219192008/http://www.next-gen.biz/news/pegi-unveils-new-ratings-symbols|archivedate=19 December 2011}}</ref> That design was slightly altered at the end of 2009, by removing the watermark and locking the URL bar underneath the age rating icon. Reprinted games from 2009 or before often still display the old designs.
{| class="wikitable" |- align="center" ! 2003 ! 2009 ! 2010 |- align="center" | [[File:PEGI 3 annotated (2003-2009).svg|60px]] | [[File:PEGI 3 annotated (2009-2010).png|60px]] | [[File:PEGI 3.svg|60px]] |}
In Portugal, two of the PEGI categories were aligned with the age ratings of the film classification system to avoid confusion; 3 was changed to 4 and 7 was changed to 6. Finland also used a modified scale, where 12 became 11 and 16 became 15. Finland fully adopted PEGI on 1 January 2007, and the standard ratings were fully enforced as well.
{| class="wikitable" |- align="center" ! Standard ! PEGI 3 ! PEGI 7 |- align="center" ! Portugal | [[File:PEGI 4.svg|60px]] | [[File:PEGI 6.svg|60px]] |}
=== Content descriptions === The nine content descriptors are:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Icon ! Content descriptor ! Explanation ! Corresponding age ratings |- | [[File:PEGI Violence.svg|60px]] | [[Violence]] | Depending on the age category, the game may contain scenes of people getting injured or dying, often by use of weapons, whether realistically or not, in a fantastical or cartoonish manner. May also contain gore, injury detail, and blood-letting. | [[File:PEGI 7.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 12.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 16.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 18.svg|20px]] |- | [[File:PEGI Bad language.svg|60px]] | [[Profanity|Bad Language]] | May contain profanity and all manner of slurs, insults, and epithets. | [[File:PEGI 12.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 16.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 18.svg|20px]] |- | [[File:PEGI Fear.svg|60px]] | [[Fear]] / [[Horror fiction|Horror]] | May contain scenes and plot elements too disturbing, overly suspenseful, or frightening to younger/sensitive players at PEGI 7 or horrifying content in the absence of violence at PEGI 12. | [[File:PEGI 7.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 12.svg|20px]] |- | [[File:PEGI Sex.svg|60px]] | [[Sex and nudity in video games|Sex]] | Depending on the age category, the game may contain scenes or references to sexual nudity, sexual posturing, characters wearing suggestive clothing, or sexual intercourse. This descriptor is not needed for non-sexual nudity. | [[File:PEGI 12.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 16.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 18.svg|20px]] |- | [[File:PEGI Drugs.svg|60px]] | [[Drugs]] / [[Alcohol (drug)|Alcohol]] | Depending on the age category, the game may contain references to or consumption of alcohol, tobacco or illegal drugs (or a fictional substance similar in effect to real-life illegal drugs). | [[File:PEGI 16.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 18.svg|20px]] |- | [[File:PEGI Gambling.svg|60px]] | [[Gambling]] | May contain elements that encourage or teach gambling. | [[File:PEGI 12.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 16.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 18.svg|20px]] |- | [[File:PEGI Discrimination.svg|60px]] | [[Discrimination]] | May contain scenes, behavior, or references to cruelty or harassment to a group of specific people based on race, religion, ethnicity, gender, ability, or sexual identity/preferences. | [[File:PEGI 18.svg|20px]] |- | [[File:PEGI Online.svg|60px]] | [[Online game|Online]] | May contain online interactions. This descriptor was discontinued by PEGI in 2015, with the majority of present-day games and all consoles allowing for online interactions. Still appears for games classified before July 2015. | [[File:PEGI 3.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 7.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 12.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 16.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 18.svg|20px]] |- | - | In-Game Purchases | To be introduced in 2018. May contain additional paid content, such as [[microtransaction]]s or [[downloadable content]], that can be purchased with real money inside the game.<ref>http://www.kotaku.co.uk/2018/08/30/uk-video-game-boxes-will-soon-warn-of-in-game-purchases</ref> | [[File:PEGI 3.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 7.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 12.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 16.svg|20px]] [[File:PEGI 18.svg|20px]] |}
== Statistics == As of December 2015, PEGI has rated more than 25,300 games. 42.2% of these games were rated 3, 15.8% rated 7, 22.3% rated 12, 12.7% rated 16 and only 7% were rated 18.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isfe.eu/sites/isfe.eu/files/attachments/pegi_annual_report_2015.pdf |title=PEGI 2015 annual report, page 13 |publisher=Pegi.info |date= |accessdate=5 November 2016}}</ref>
Of all the games that were rated in 2015 (1855 games in total): * 64.7% (1201) have the Violence content descriptor. * 25.4% (472) have the Online content descriptor. * 18.4% (341) have the Bad Language content descriptor. * 7.7% (142) have the Fear content descriptor. * 4.7% (88) have the Sex content descriptor. * 1.4% (26) have the Gambling content descriptor. * 1.2% (23) have the Drugs content descriptor. * No games have the Discrimination content descriptor.
== PEGI and the European Union == A consumer survey commissioned by [[ISFE]] in 2012 demonstrated that the PEGI age rating labels are recognised on average by 51% of respondents in 16 different countries (highest: France 72%; lowest: Czech Republic 28%), while 86% of all respondents found them to be clear and 89% found them useful.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isfe.eu/sites/isfe.eu/files/attachments/euro_summary_-_isfe_consumer_study.pdf |title=Videogames in Europe: Consumer Study - European Summary Report |publisher=isfe.eu |date= |accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref>
PEGI is an example of European harmonisation. The European Commission supports the PEGI self-regulation: "PEGI appears to have achieved good results and PEGI On-line is also a promising initiative, making of PEGI a good example of self-regulation in line with the better regulation agenda."<ref>Communication from the commission of the European parliament, the council, the European economic and social committee and the committee of the regions, on the protection of consumers, in particular minors, in respect of the use of video games, Brussels, 2008, p.9</ref> Moreover, the European Parliament in its last report on protection of consumers "takes the view that the PEGI system for rating games is an important tool which has improved transparency for consumers, especially parents, when buying games by enabling them to make a considered choice as to whether a game is suitable for children".<ref>Toine Manders, Report of the European Parliament on the protection of the consumers, in particular minors, in respect of the use of video games, 2009, p.6. article 24</ref>
== Rating process == To obtain the ratings for any piece of interactive software, the applicant submits the game with other supporting materials and completes a content declaration,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pegi.info/en/index/id/1184/media/pdf/235.pdf|title=PEGI Assessment Form|publisher=Pegi.info|date=|accessdate=6 November 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111215170513/http://www.pegi.info/en/index/id/1184/media/pdf/235.pdf|archivedate=15 December 2011}}</ref> all of which is evaluated by an '''independent administrator''' called the [[Netherlands Institute for the Classification of Audiovisual Media]] (NICAM). It is based on the Dutch [[Kijkwijzer]] system as well.<ref>[http://www.kijkwijzer.nl/pagina.php?id=3 NICAM website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221174849/http://www.kijkwijzer.nl/pagina.php?id=3 |date=21 December 2008 }}</ref> Following the evaluation the applicant will receive a license to use the rating logos. If the applicant disagrees with the rating, they can ask for an explanation or make a complaint to the complaints board. Consumers may also make complaints to this board.
Although PEGI was established by an industry body (ISFE) the ratings are given by a body independent of the industry and the whole system is overseen by a number of different Boards and Committees. There is the '''PEGI Council''', composed mainly by national representatives for PEGI, that recommends adjustments to the code in light of social, legal and technological developments. Members of the PEGI Council are recruited for their skill and experience from among parent/consumer body representatives, child psychologists, media specialists, civil servants, academics and legal advisers versed in the protection of minors in Europe.<ref name="pegi">{{cite web|url=http://www.pegi.info/en/index/id/41/ |title=Website PEGI |publisher=Pegi.info |date= |accessdate=29 June 2011}}</ref>
There is also a '''Complaints Board''' with experts from various European countries. They deal with complaints related to breaches of requirements of the code of conduct or to age rating recommendations. Should a complaint be received from a consumer or publisher regarding a rating given to a game and no satisfactory settlement can be reached by the PEGI administrator through discussion, explanation or negotiation the complainant may formally request the Complaints Board to mediate. Three board members will then convene, hear the complaint and decide on a ruling. Publishers using the PEGI system are bound by the decision of the Complaints Board. Consequently, they are obliged to carry out any corrective actions required and, in cases of non-compliance, are subject to sanctions as laid out by the code.
== Global cooperation in IARC == In 2013, PEGI co-founded the [[International Age Rating Coalition]] with [[Unterhaltungssoftware Selbstkontrolle|USK]] and the [[Entertainment Software Rating Board|ESRB]]. IARC aims to streamline the rating of digitally distributed games and apps by providing a single online system that produces age ratings for all participating regions. By filling out one questionnaire, a publisher instantaneously receives ratings from PEGI, [[Unterhaltungssoftware Selbstkontrolle|USK]], [[Entertainment Software Rating Board|ESRB]], [[Australian Classification Board|ACB]] and others.<ref name="ign">{{cite web|url=http://au.ign.com/articles/2014/09/01/getting-digitally-distributed-games-classified-in-australia-to-be-cost-free|title=Getting Digitally-Distributed Games Classified in Australia to Be Cost-Free - IGN|publisher=au.ign.com|accessdate=25 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="dealspwn">{{cite web|url=http://www.dealspwn.com/international-age-ratings-system-160904|title=New International Age Ratings System Launching Worldwide Next Year | Video Game Deals & UK News | Dealspwn.com|publisher=dealspwn.com|accessdate=25 March 2016}}</ref>
== PEGI committees == There are a number of committees to ensure the system keeps functioning properly.
* '''Experts Group''': The PEGI Experts Group is made up of academics working in the fields of psychology and sociology, and representatives from NICAM, VSC, and the games industry. It works on adapting and modifying the PEGI questionnaire and the underlying criteria to take account of technological and content developments and recommendations made by the PEGI Council or circumstances brought to light by the complaints procedure. * '''Legal Committee''': Since PEGI is a voluntary system it runs in conjunction with, and is subordinate to, existing national laws, whether they prohibit certain content or establish mandatory rating systems. The Legal Committee's role is to advise PEGI s.a. of any changes to national legislation within participating countries that could affect the voluntary age rating system. * '''Enforcement Committee''': The Enforcement Committee is charged with implementing the recommendations of the PEGI Council and, more generally, of ensuring the enforcement of the provisions of the PEGI Code of Conduct, including conclusion of the Complaints Board.
== PEGI Online == In 2007, the PEGI Online division of PEGI was formed as an addition to the PEGI system for online games. Goals include giving young people in Europe improved protection against unsuitable online gaming content and educating parents on how to ensure safe online play.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pegi.info/page/pegi-online |title=PEGI Online Website |publisher=Pegionline.info |date= |accessdate=29 June 2011}}</ref> This project is supported directly by the European Commission:
{{Quote|PEGI On-line, which was launched in June 2007 and co-funded by the Safer Internet Programme, is the logical development of the PEGI system, designed to better protect young people against unsuitable gaming content and to help parents to understand the risks and potential for harm within this environment.<ref>Communication from the commission of the European parliament, the council, the European economic and social committee and the committee of the regions, on the protection of consumers, in particular minors, in respect of the use of video games, Brussels, 2008, p.3.</ref>}}
PEGI Online is based on four principles: * The PEGI Online Safety Code and Framework Contract which is signed by all participants * The PEGI Online Logo which will be displayed by holders of a licence * The website for applicants and for the general public * An independent administration, advice, and dispute settlement process
The licence to display the PEGI Online Logo is granted by the PEGI Online Administrator to any online gameplay service provider that meets the requirements set out in the PEGI Online Safety Code (POSC).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pegi.info/page/pegi-online-safety-code |title=PEGI Online Safety Code |publisher=Pegionline.info }}</ref>
== Usage == PEGI is the standard age rating system for video games in 37 European countries and Israel, but products with PEGI labels can be found across the globe alongside other rating systems as a result of import for linguistic reasons (e.g.: English versions in South Africa and the United Arab Emirates, Spanish or Portuguese versions in Latin America). The official status of PEGI ratings varies from country to country, depending on the way national legislation deals with age classification and the protection of minors. In some countries, PEGI is the [[de facto]] standard without specific regulation, other countries have officially acknowledged PEGI as the sole system for age ratings, while yet another number of countries have incorporated the PEGI rating system into laws governing the age classification of media, making the labels enforceable in retail.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width: 155px;" | Country ! Status ! style="width: 120px;" | Local system |- | {{flagu|Albania}} | De facto use of the PEGI labels, no specific legislative basis or official support. | |- | {{flagu|Austria}} | PEGI is legally adopted and enforceable in the regions of [[Vienna]] and [[Carinthia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bupp.at/de/jugendschutz|title= Austrian government page explaining PEGI and its status}}</ref> In the latter region, USK labels are also allowed. Represented in the PEGI Council. | |- | {{flagu|Belgium}} | Officially supports PEGI, but there is no specific legislative basis. | |- | {{flagu|Bosnia and Herzegovina}} | De facto use of the PEGI labels, no specific legislative basis or official support. | |- | {{flagu|Bulgaria}} | Officially supports PEGI and is represented in the PEGI Council, but there is no specific legislative basis. | |- | {{flagu|Croatia}} | De facto use of the PEGI labels, no specific legislative basis or official support. | |- | {{flagu|Cyprus}} | Officially supports PEGI, but there is no specific legislative basis. | |- | {{flagu|Czech Republic}} | Officially supports PEGI, but there is no specific legislative basis. | |- | {{flagu|Denmark}} | Officially supports PEGI and is represented in the PEGI Council, but there is no specific legislative basis. | |- | {{flagu|Estonia}} | Officially supports PEGI, but there is no specific legislative basis. | |- | {{flagu|Finland}} | In Finland, games with PEGI ratings are exempt from mandatory classification with national age symbols. Both classifications are enforced by the penal code. Represented in the PEGI Council. | [[National Audiovisual Institute (Finland)|KAVI]] |- | {{flagu|France}} | France has adopted legislation making classification of video games with age labels mandatory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nextinpact.com/news/94139-le-classification-jeux-video-bientot-obligatoire-en-france.htm|title= Article explaining plans for legal change in France}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/14/amendements/1808/AN/68.asp|title= Text of the amendment proposing the change}}</ref> Represented in the PEGI Council. | |- | {{flagu|Greece}} | Officially supports PEGI and is represented in the PEGI Council, but there is no specific legislative basis. | |- | {{flagu|Germany}} | The USK system is adopted and enforced.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usk.de/fileadmin/documents/Publisher_Bereich/Statut_USK.online_EN.pdf|title= Statutes of the USK system}}</ref> PEGI is not formally recognised, although PEGI labelling can be found on games along with the USK rating. Not represented on the PEGI Council. | [[Unterhaltungssoftware Selbstkontrolle|USK]] |- | {{flagu|Hungary}} | De facto use of the PEGI labels, no specific legislative basis or official support. | |- | {{flagu|Iceland}} | PEGI is officially supported and age classifications are mandatory for video games by law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.althingi.is/altext/stjt/2006.062.html|title= Icelandic Media Act (2006)}}</ref> | |- | {{flagu|Ireland}} | PEGI ratings are exempt from mandatory classification by IFCO, which adopts PEGI. IFCO is still legally empowered to ban certain video game content from the market. Represented in the PEGI Council. | |- | {{flagu|Israel}} | PEGI has been adopted by law as the mandatory classification system for video games in Israel.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/israel-duty-to-label-computer-games/|title= Article detailing legal requirement to use PEGI in Israel}}</ref> | |- | {{flagu|Italy}} | Officially supports PEGI and is represented in the PEGI Council, but there is no specific legislative basis. | |- | {{flagu|Latvia}} | De facto use of the PEGI labels, no specific legislative basis or official support. | |- | {{flagu|Lithuania}} | Lithuanian legislation has adopted PEGI which is exempt from mandatory classification with national age symbols. Both classifications are enforced by the penal code as of November 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.e-tar.lt/portal/lt/legalAct/TAR.66BE5E9704D1|title= Legislative text specifying PEGI as the labelling system for video games in Lithuania}}</ref> | |- | {{flagu|Luxembourg}} | Officially supports PEGI and is represented in the PEGI Council, but there is no specific legislative basis. | |- | {{flagu|Macedonia}} | De facto use of the PEGI labels, no specific legislative basis or official support. | |- | {{flagu|Malta}} | Officially supports PEGI and is represented in the PEGI Council, PEGI is the legally enforceable system for game classification in Malta since January 2016. | |- | {{flagu|Montenegro}} | De facto use of the PEGI labels, no specific legislative basis or official support. | |- | {{flagu|Netherlands}} | PEGI is officially adopted and legislation is in place to enforce age classification in shops where video games are sold.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.wetboek-online.nl/wet/Wetboek%20van%20Strafrecht/240a.html|title= Penal code text specifying enforcement of sales restriction of certain media content to minors}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/binaries/rijksoverheid/documenten/rapporten/2013/07/22/betere-bescherming-van-jongeren-tegen-mogelijk-schadelijk-beeldmateriaal/lp-v-j-0000003814.pdf|title= Government document outlining the role of PEGI in legal context}}</ref> | |- | {{flagu|Norway}} | Officially supports PEGI and is represented in the PEGI Council, but there is no specific legislative basis. | |- | {{flagu|Poland}} | Officially supports PEGI and is represented in the PEGI Council, but there is no specific legislative basis. | |- | {{flagu|Portugal}} | PEGI has officially been adopted by the Portuguese Classification Board IGAC. | [[Inspecção Geral das Actividades Culturais|IGAC]] |- | {{flagu|Romania}} | Officially supports PEGI, but there is no specific legislative basis. | |- | {{flagu|Serbia}} | De facto use of the PEGI labels, no specific legislative basis or official support. | |- | {{flagu|Slovakia}} | De facto use of the PEGI labels, but Slovak media law obliges distributors to add national age labels (generally using stickers). | |- | {{flagu|Slovenia}} | Officially supports PEGI, but there is no specific legislative basis. | |- | {{flagu|Spain}} | Officially supports PEGI and is represented in the PEGI Council, but there is no specific legislative basis. | |- | {{flagu|Sweden}} | Officially supports PEGI and is represented in the PEGI Council, but there is no specific legislative basis. | |- | {{flagu|Switzerland}} | Switzerland is preparing national legislation to make classification of video games with age labels legally binding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bsv.admin.ch/aktuell/medien/00120/index.html?lang=de&msg-id=57226|title= Swiss federal government announcement}}</ref> | |- | {{flagu|Turkey}} | De facto use of the PEGI labels, no specific legislative basis or official support. | |- | {{flagu|United Kingdom}} | PEGI is the legally enforceable system for game classification in the UK since 30 July 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mcvuk.com/business/pegi-games-ratings-come-into-force-today|title=MCV: PEGI ratings come into force today}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-19042908|title=BBC News: UK enforces PEGI video game ratings system}}</ref> Has official support for PEGI, and is represented in the PEGI Council. |[[BBFC]] |}

{{coord|42|41|46|N|23|19|35|E|region:BG|display=title}}[[Image:Royal Palace Sofia.jpg|thumb|350px|right|The [[National Art Gallery (Bulgaria)|National Art Gallery]] at Battenberg Square 1]]
[[Image:RoyalPalaceSofia.jpg|left|thumb|250px|The former royal palace in 1917.]]
'''Prince Alexander I Square''' ({{lang-bg|площад Княз Александър I, Ploshtad Knyaz Aleksandar I}}), often called simply '''Battenberg Square''' (площад Батенберг) is the [[List of city squares by size|largest square]] of [[Sofia]], the capital of [[Bulgaria]]. It is named after [[Alexander, Prince of Bulgaria|Alexander Joseph of Battenberg]] (Alexander I of Bulgaria), the first prince of modern Bulgaria. During the [[History of the People's Republic of Bulgaria|Communist rule of Bulgaria]], the square was named '''September 9th''' '''Square''', after a coup on September 9, 1944, made the country a [[Communist state]]. Before 1944, the square was known as '''Tsar's Square''' because the former royal palace, now the [[National Art Gallery (Bulgaria)|National Art Gallery]] was located there. It was the site of the [[Georgi Dimitrov Mausoleum]] from 1949 until 1999. It is arguably the most suitable place in Sofia for major open-air concerts such as the concert series ''"Opera on the Square"'', demonstrations, parades (including the military parade on [[St George's Day#St. George.27s Day in Bulgaria|St George's Day]]) and other large-scale events.
== Events == [[File:UnitMD Parade.jpg|thumb|A Moldovan military band on the square in 2009.]] During the communist era, September 9th Square was the main site of civil and military parades in honor of [[International Workers' Day]], The [[Bulgarian coup d'état of 1944]], The [[Great October Socialist Revolution]], and in 1981 the [[1300th Anniversary of the Bulgarian State Parade|1300th Anniversary of the Bulgarian State]]. The government leaders ascended to the top of the Georgi Dimitrov Mausoleum to view these parades. After the fall of communism in 1989, only parades were held in honor of Armed Forces Day.
==External links== * [http://stara-sofia.com/ploalexander.html A gallery of early photos of the square]
{{bulgaria-stub}}
[[Category:Squares in Sofia]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox ethnic group| |group = Sichuanese people
巴蜀人 巴蜀民系 |region1 = '''Total population''' |region2 = {{Flagicon|China}} [[People's Republic of China]] |pop2 = [[Sichuan]]
[[Chongqing]] |region3 = {{Flagicon|Taiwan}} [[Republic of China]] (on [[Taiwan]]) |pop3 = As part of [[Mainland Chinese|Mainlander]] population |languages = Historically [[Ba-Shu Chinese]], also known as Old Sichuanese.
Presently [[Sichuanese Mandarin|Sichuanese]] dialects of [[Southwestern Mandarin]]. |religions = [[Mahayana Buddhism]], [[Taoism]], [[Confucianism]], and [[Chinese folk religion]] |related = other [[Han Chinese]] }} The '''Sichuanese''', '''Sze Chuan''' or '''Si Ch'uan''' (previous romanize spelling) people ([[Sichuanese Mandarin|Sichuanese]]: 巴蜀人 Ba1su2ren2; [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]: {{IPA|[pa55su21zən21]}}; alternatively 川人, 川渝人, 四川人 or 巴蜀民系) are a subgroup of [[Han Chinese]] living in mostly [[Sichuan]] province and [[Chongqing]] municipality of [[China]]. ==History== [[File:E-MJ - engineering and mining journal (1920) (14578888028).jpg|thumb|left|A river towing party of Sichuanese [[coolie]]s, 1920.]] Beginning from the 9th century BC, [[Shu (state)|Shu]] (on the [[Chengdu Plain]]) and [[Ba (state)|Ba]] (which had its first capital at [[Enshi City]] in [[Hubei]] and controlled part of the [[Han River (Shaanxi and Hubei)|Han Valley]]) emerged as cultural and administrative centers where two rival kingdoms were established. Although eventually the [[Qin dynasty]] destroyed the kingdoms of Shu and Ba, the Qin government accelerated the technological and agricultural advancements of Sichuan making it comparable to that of the [[Yellow River]] Valley. The now-extinct [[Ba-Shu Chinese|Ba-Shu language]] was derived from Qin-era settlers and represents the earliest documented division from what is now called [[Middle Chinese]]. During the [[Yuan dynasty|Yuan]] and [[Ming dynasty|Ming]] dynasties, the population of Sichuan where [[Chengdu-Chongqing dialect]] is now spoken at was reduced through wars and the [[bubonic plague]] and settlers arrived from the area of modern [[Hunan]], [[Hubei]], [[Guangdong]] and [[Jiangxi]], replacing the earlier spoken Chinese dialect with a new standard.{{cite journal |title=The Culmination of a Chinese Peasant Rebellion: Chang Hsien-chung in Szechwan, 1644–46 |author= James B. Parsons |journal=The Journal of Asian Studies |volume=16 |issue=3 |pages=387–400 |publisher= |url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?aid=7001496 |year=1957 |doi=10.2307/2941233}}{{cite book|author=Yingcong Dai|title=The Sichuan Frontier and Tibet: Imperial Strategy in the Early Qing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DYHfVVAAf_kC&pg=PA16#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=2009|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=978-0-295-98952-5|pages=16–}}{{cite book|title=Migration and settlement in Sichuan, 1644-1796|first=Robert Eric |last=Entenmann|publisher=Harvard University|year=1982}} ===Recent history=== Many migrant workers from rural Sichuan have migrated to other parts of the country, where they often face [[regional discrimination in China|discrimination]] in employment, housing etc.Handbook of Chinese Migration: Identity and Wellbeing A common [[stereotype]] about Sichuanese people is that they are hot tempered.{{cite book|title=Handbook of Chinese Migration: Identity and Wellbeing|first1= Robyn R. |last1=Iredale|first2=Fei |last2=Guo}} ==Language== {{Main|Sichuanese Mandarin|Minjiang dialect|Ba-Shu Chinese}} {{See also|Bashu culture}} [[File:Sichuanese in China.png|thumb|right|Locations of present-day Sichuanese speakers.]] The Sichuanese once spoke their own variety of spoken Chinese called [[Ba-Shu Chinese]], or Old Sichuanese before it became extinct during the Ming dynasty. Now most of them speak [[Sichuanese Mandarin]]. The [[Minjiang dialect]]s are thought by some linguists to be a bona fide descendant of Old Sichuanese due to many characteristics of [[Ba-Shu Chinese]] phonology and vocabulary being found in the dialects,试论宋代巴蜀方言与现代四川方言的关系》">刘晓南（2009年第8卷第6期），《试论宋代巴蜀方言与现代四川方言的关系——兼谈文献考证的一个重要功用：追寻失落的方言》，语言科学 but there is no conclusive evidence whether Minjiang dialects are derived from Old Sichuanese or Southwestern Mandarin. ==Cuisine== {{Main|Sichuan cuisine}} Sichuan is well known for its spicy cuisine and use of [[Sichuan pepper]]s due to its more arid climate. ==Notable people== Well known Sichuanese people are such as: * [[Chen Shou]], official and writer * [[Huang Jiguang]], highly decorated soldier during the Korean War * [[Zhao Yiman]], resistance fighter * [[Liu Yonghao]], businessman * [[GAI (musician)|GAI]], rapper, singer, and songwriter * [[Wang Jianlin]], business magnate, investor, and philanthropist * [[Jiang Zhuyun]], revolutionary martyr * [[Zhang Daqian]], artists * [[Wang Xiaoya]], television host and media personality * [[Li Yifeng]], actor and singer * [[Li Yuchun]], singer, songwriter, and actress * [[Tan Weiwei]], singer and actress * [[Luo Ruiqing]], army officer and politician * [[Su Shi]], writer, poet, painter, calligrapher, pharmacologist, gastronome, and statesman * [[Su Xun]], writer * [[Su Zhe]], politician and essayist * [[Li Bai]], poet * [[Zhuo Wenjun]], poet * [[Yang Xiong (author)|Yang Xiong]], poet, philosopher, and politician * [[Zheng Ji (biochemist)|Zheng Ji]], nutritionist and pioneering biochemist * [[Deng Xiaoping]], revolutionary and politician * [[Ba Jin]], author and political activist * [[Zhu De]], general, warlord, politician, and revolutionary * [[Zhang Lan]], political activist * [[Zou Rong]], revolutionary martyr * [[Guo Moruo]], author, poet, historian, archaeologist, and government official * [[Zhang Qun]], premier of the Republic of China * [[Bai Ling]], actress ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Commonscat|Sichuan people}} {{Sichuan topics}} {{Han subgroups}} [[Category:Subgroups of the Han Chinese]] [[Category:Sichuan]] {{Asia-ethno-group-stub}} {{China-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=March 2015}}
Imaginary continent whose western territories serve as background to twelve [[fantasy]] [[novella]]s or [[short story|short stories]] by {{ill|Timothée Rey|fr}}, a French author, gathered in the collection ''Des nouvelles du Tibbar''.<ref>Published by {{ill|Les Moutons Électriques|fr}}, Lyon (France), May 2010, {{ISBN|978-2-915793-88-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.noosfere.org/icarus/livres/niourf.asp?numlivre=2146574998|title=Des nouvelles du Tibbar, Timothée REY|first=|last=noocontact@noosfere.com|website=www.noosfere.org}}</ref>
The collection includes five accurate maps, appendices describing the time units (and others measurement units), and twelve graphic documents with characteristic details of this part of the continent.
==Stories== * 01 - "Sur la route d’Ongle" * 02 - "Mille et mille surgeons du Foisonneur" * 03 - "Lacnae b’Asac" * 04 - "Dans l’antre du Sanguinaire" * 05 - "Ce qu’il advint des ravisseurs de la Tomate chantante" * 06 - "Le Tronc, la Grume et le Fluent" * 07 - "Magma mia !" * 08 - "Suivre à travers le bleu cet éclair puis cette ombre" (Price: {{ill|Prix Rosny aîné|fr}} 2011, category: short story).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fantasy.fr/articles/view/17661/les-laureats-du-prix-rosny-aine-2011|title=Les lauréats du prix Rosny aîné 2011|website=www.fantasy.fr}}</ref> * 09 - "Le jardin de nains du Ninja Radin" * 10 - "Jeunes sirènes lascives pour matelots bourrus" * 11 - "Mon père, ce bouffon au sourire si torve" * 12 - "Deux hougôlouns dans le vent du soir"
== References == {{reflist}}

page.title: United Nations Integrated Office in Burundi

revision.comment: added [[Category:Burundi and the United Nations]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox United Nations | name = United Nations Integrated Office in Burundi | image = | caption = | type = Peace Support Mission | acronyms = BINUB | head = [[Youssef Mahmoud]] | status = Active | established = 1 January 2007 | website = http://bnub.unmissions.org/ | parent = [[United Nations Security Council]] | subsidiaries = | footnotes = }}{{Politics of Burundi}} The '''United Nations Integrated Office in Burundi''' ('''BINUB''') was established by the [[United Nations Security Council]] to support the government of [[Burundi]] in its efforts towards long-term peace and stability and to replace the work of [[United Nations Operation in Burundi]] (ONUB).<ref name="UN_SRES17192006">{{UN document |docid=S-RES-1719(2006) |type=Resolution |body=Security Council |year=2006 |resolution_number=1719 |accessdate=2008-08-28|date=25 October 2006}}</ref> Its mandate was scheduled to begin on 1 January 2007 for an initial 12 months, and its creation and mission was as a result of recommendations in a report by the Secretary-General.<ref name="UN_S2006429">{{UN document |docid=S-2006-429 |type=Document |body=Security Council |year=2006 |document_number=429 |accessdate=2008-08-28|title=Seventh report of the Secretary-General on the United Nations Operation in Burundi|date=21 June 2006}}</ref><ref name="UN_S2006429Add1">{{UN document |docid=S-2006-429-Add.1 |type=Document |body=Security Council |year=2006 |document_number=429-Add.1 |accessdate=2008-08-28|title=Seventh report of the Secretary-General on the United Nations Operation in Burundi - Addendum|date=14 August 2006}}</ref>
The previous UN mission in Burundi, ONUB, was created to facilitate the implementation of the peace agreements signed between the previous government and the [[CNDD-FDD]] rebel group. The CNDD-FDD's leader Pierre Nkurunziza went on to win the Burundian elections in 2005, and his party effectively controls the Burundian government.
The reasons for establishing a second mission in Burundi, following directly on the ONUB missions, was the ceasefire agreement reached between the new CNDD-FDD government and the last remaining rebel group Palipehutu-FNL. This ceasefire agreement was signed on 7 September 2006 in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, after mediation by South Africa in talks that began in May. Among the key points in the agreement were a complete cessation of hostilities, temporary immunity for FNL fighters and the demobilization of these troops and their subsequent integration into the armed forces of Burundi, in line with earlier peace agreements in this conflict that all stipulated power-sharing arrangements in the security sector.
The BINUB mission was created to facilitate the implementation of this ceasefire agreement, with the most important point of the mandate being the support of the implementation of the modalities of the agreement, assistance in the reform of the security sector and support of the reintegration of ex-combatants[http://documents-dds-ny.un.org/doc/UNDOC/GEN/N06/585/71/PDF/N0658571.pdf?OpenElement]. The Burundian government also requested the BINUB to help in the establishment of [[rule of law]], [[good governance]] and [[freedom of press]] and media.
The mandate of BINUB currently extends to the end of 2010.<ref name="UN_SRES17912007">{{UN document |docid=S-RES-1791(2007) |type=Resolution |body=Security Council |year=2007 |resolution_number=1791 |accessdate=2008-08-28|date=19 December 2007}}</ref>
It was replaced by the [[United Nations Office in Burundi]] (BNUB) on 1 January 2011.<ref>http://bnub.unmissions.org/Default.aspx?tabid=2963&language=en-US</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://binub.turretdev.com/ BINUB] ''official UN website'' *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070116023649/http://www.un.org/Depts/dpko/missions/onub/ ONUB archives] from the [[UN]] *[http://presszoom.com/story_120058.html News story]
{{DEFAULTSORT:United Nations Integrated Office In Burundi}} [[Category:Politics of Burundi]] [[Category:United Nations Security Council mandates|1719]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2001]] [[Category:Burundi and the United Nations]]

{{Infobox radio station | name = WRMI | image = | city = [[Okeechobee, Florida]] | area = the [[Americas]], the [[Caribbean]], [[Europe]], [[Africa]], [[Middle East]] and [[Asia]] | branding = Radio Miami International | slogan = | frequency = See [[#Frequencies|Frequencies]] | language = [[English language|English]]
[[Spanish language|Spanish]]
[[French language|French]]
[[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]
[[Slovak language|Slovak]] | airdate = June 14, [[1994 in radio|1994]] | format = [[Brokered programming]] | owner = Radio Miami International, Inc. | website = [http://www.wrmi.net/ www.wrmi.net] | callsign_meaning = '''R'''adio '''M'''iami '''I'''nternational }} '''WRMI''' (Radio Miami International) is a [[shortwave radio|shortwave]] [[radio station]] broadcasting from [[Okeechobee, Florida|Okeechobee]], [[Florida]], [[United States]]. WRMI is a commercial radio station that sells airtime to businesses and organizations. It also relays several international news stations including [[Radio Ukraine International]], [[Radio Slovakia International]], [[Radio Tirana]], [[Radio France International]], Famagusta Gazette Radio, [[Radio Prague]], the Italian Broadcasting Corporation, [[NHK World#Radio Japan|NHK World Radio Japan]], and [[Radiodifusión Argentina al Exterior]], all of which would otherwise be difficult to receive in the [[Western Hemisphere]].[http://primetimeshortwave.com/america.txt English Schedule to the Americas] ''Primetime Shortwave''[https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1nEVwCMB9RSKowLzLXamyayVpCzjmPAw_SB1r3YOdzQc/edit#gid=0 Schedule] WRMI official site It also features headline news stories from the [[Voice of America]], several religious programs, as well as original and syndicated programs.[https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1DOJYj_yHcP5DrAIEQY80RghMZBeHtcIGXsB5wztJDAo/edit?hl=en#gid=0 WRMI Schedule for 9.955 MHz] WRMI official site According to its 1996 station record from the [[Federal Communications Commission]], WRMI's broadcast target zones were the [[Caribbean]], [[Central America]] and [[South America]]. In particular, much of its programming was targeted towards [[Cuba]]. However, as of 2016, WRMI had 23 antennas targeting many zones worldwide. Its broadcasts are also easily received in the [[United States]] and [[Canada]]. WRMI airs programs in [[English language|English]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[French language|French]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], and [[Slovak language|Slovak]]. == History == The station began broadcasting on June 14, 1994 with a 50,000-watt transmitter and two antennas located near Miami, Florida.{{cite web |url= https://transition.fcc.gov/ib/sand/neg/hf_web-dec02/xwrmi20.txt |title= WRMI Station record 1996 to 2003 |website= [[Federal Communications Commission]] |date= November 1996 }} In December 2013, they purchased the [[WYFR]] transmission complex from [[Family Radio]] in [[Okeechobee, Florida]].{{cite web |url= http://licensing.fcc.gov/ibfsweb/ib.page.FetchPN?report_key=1083537 |title= International High Frequency – WYFR to WRMI |website= Federal Communications Commission |date= April 10, 2015 }} This new facility includes a dozen 100,000-watt transmitters plus two 50,000-watt transmitters and several antennas to cover all parts of the world.{{cite web |url= http://licensing.fcc.gov/myibfs/displayIHFLicense.do?filingKey=959649 |title= WRMI – file IHF-RWL-20120627-00005 |website= Federal Communications Commission |accessdate= 21 February 2016}} == Frequencies == WRMI currently broadcasts on the following frequencies{{cite web|title=WRMI A17|url=https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1nEVwCMB9RSKowLzLXamyayVpCzjmPAw_SB1r3YOdzQc/edit#gid=0|website=WRMI A17 Frequencies|publisher=WRMI|accessdate=1 May 2017}} * 7.78MHz @ 44° to Eastern North America, Europe, the Middle East and North Africa * 5.985MHz @ 222° to Central America, Mexico and the Caribbean * 15.77MHz @ 44° to Eastern North America, Europe, the Middle East and North Africa * 11.53MHz @ 160° to Latin America * 9.455MHz @ 285° to Mexico and Western North America * 9.395MHz @ 355° to Eastern North America * 21.525MHz @ 87° to Africa * 11.825MHz @ 355° to Eastern North America * 11.58MHz @ 44° to Eastern North America, Europe, the Middle East and North Africa * 9.955MHz @ 160° to Latin America * 7.57MHz @ 315° to Western North America * 5.85MHz @ 315° to Western North America * 7.73MHz @ 285° to Mexico and Western North America * 5.95MHz @ 181° to Cuba, the Caribbean and Central America == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.wrmi.net/ WRMI] official Web site * [http://www.wrmi.net/pb/wp_d12a1732/wp_d12a1732.html WRMI transmission schedules] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051101013944/http://www181.pair.com/otsw/Wavescan/wavescan494.html 10th Anniversary of WRMI] article in Wavescan 494, June 20, 2004
